summary: This is a 2021 opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF). The evidence included Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case, which were subject to a protective order. The court rejects Maxwell's arguments that obtaining this evidence violated her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, her Fourth Amendment rights, and her due process rights.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, moving to suppress evidence (her deposition transcripts) obtained from her prior civil litigation. She is accused of making false statements in those depositions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York who authored this opinion and order denying Maxwell's motion to suppress.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual, alongside Maxwell, whom the plaintiff in the civil case accused of sexual abuse. The government's investigation into Epstein was formally opened in 2018.

persons.name: McMahon
persons.context: Then-Chief Judge who heard the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in the civil case and granted it in a sealed opinion dated April 9, 2019.

persons.name: Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied a similar government application in another case, applying the same legal standard but reaching a different conclusion on the facts.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: An unnamed Assistant U.S. Attorney in the SDNY who met with attorneys from BSF in February 2016 and later forwarded their emails when the Epstein investigation opened in 2018.

connections.description: Maxwell is identified in the AUSA's notes from a 2016 meeting as Epstein's 'head recruiter' of underage girls, and the civil suit accused both of sexually abusing the plaintiff.
BSF represented the plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) in the civil defamation case against Maxwell. The firm later complied with a grand jury subpoena for case documents.
Attorneys from BSF met with the AUSA in February 2016 to provide information on possible criminal conduct by Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Suppress
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued this opinion and order, denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence obtained via the grand jury subpoena to BSF.

keyFacts: The government obtained Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil case via a grand jury subpoena served on her opponent's law firm, Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

The court ruled Maxwell had no reasonable expectation of privacy in documents produced in civil litigation, even under a protective order, and thus their acquisition did not violate the Fourth Amendment.

The court held that a civil protective order provides no guarantee against the use of testimony in a subsequent criminal case, so Maxwell's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination was not violated.
The court found Maxwell failed to make a substantial showing that the government deliberately misled the court when seeking modification of the protective order, so no due process violation occurred.
Much of the evidence obtained, including Maxwell's deposition transcripts, had already been unsealed and made public by court order in the civil case by the time of this opinion.
